Total_Links:
Tata Power announced their Q4 and full-year FY25 results, reporting a 16.5% year-on-year increase in consolidated net profit to ₹1,043 crore for the quarter ended March 31, 2025.

Revenue from operations for Q4 FY25 rose 8% to ₹17,096 crore.

The company's board recommended a final dividend of ₹2.25 per share for FY25.

They reported strong performance in the renewables segment (solar manufacturing and generation) and improved performance by Odisha distribution companies contributing to the growth in profitability.

Tata Power incurred a capex of ₹4,100 crore in Q4 FY25, bringing the total capex for FY25 to ₹16,200 crore, according to a May 14, 2025 earnings transcript.

They plan a capex of ₹25,000 crore for FY26, with 60% allocated to the renewable vertical and 30% to the transmission and distribution business.

Tata Power commissioned 1 GW of renewable energy capacity in FY25 and plans to add 2.5-2.7 GW in FY26.

The company aims to achieve nearly 70% clean and green energy by 2030, supported by renewable projects and pumped hydro projects under construction or planned.

Their solar rooftop business saw a 40% rise in revenues in Q4 FY25 to ₹865 crore and a 72% increase in EBITDA to ₹132 crore.

TP Solar Limited, Tata Power's solar manufacturing arm, won a ₹632 crore contract from SECI to supply 292.5 MWp DCR solar modules.

Tata Power's solar cell and module manufacturing plant has been operating at over 90% utilization.

The company produced 879 MW of modules and 650 MW of cells in Q4 FY25 and expects to supply 3,700 MW in FY26.

They are exploring opportunities in the power distribution sector, particularly in Uttar Pradesh, where two distribution companies are slated for privatization.

Tata Power is also interested in nuclear power generation in India.

Discussions are ongoing with the five procurer states served by the Mundra power plant to conclude a long-term arrangement for power supply until 2038.

News and updates related to Tata Power as of May 1, 2025
